importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the game when Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance in the NLCS, culminating in the Dodgers' sweep of the Brewers and their return to the World Series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The postseason game on October 18, 2025, marked a pivotal moment in the Dodgers' 2025 postseason run, showcasing a record-setting performance by Ohtani that defined the outcome of the NLCS.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching shutout innings.
The Los Angeles Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in four games, becoming the first team to sweep an NLCS since Washington in 2019 and the first to do so in a best-of-seven series since 2022.
Ohtani's performance is considered one of the greatest individual postseason performances in baseball history, earning him NLCS MVP honors and cementing his status as a franchise cornerstone.
The Dodgers advanced to the World Series for the 23rd time in franchise history and the first time in nine seasons, with a strong postseason run that included a 9-1 playoff performance.
The Milwaukee Brewers, who had a 97-win regular season, were eliminated for the third time in seven playoff appearances and failed to reach the World Series for the first time since 1982.
The Dodgers' dominant pitching and defensive execution, including a 28 2/3-inning performance with just two earned runs and 35 strikeouts, contributed significantly to the sweep.
The game is being remembered as a landmark moment in baseball history, with many calling it 'the Shohei Ohtani game' and praising the sheer magnitude of his performance.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Japanese-American professional baseball player and two-time three-time MVP
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani delivered a historic performance by hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters, becoming the first player to hit three homers in a postseason game and earning NLCS MVP honors. His two-way excellence defined the game and propelled the Dodgers to a decisive victory.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team based in Los Angeles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, clinching their return to the World Series and marking a significant milestone in franchise history as the first to sweep an NLCS in 16 years and the first to do so since 2022.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professional baseball team based in Milwaukee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers were swept in the NLCS by the Dodgers, marking their third elimination in seven playoff appearances and their first World Series absence since 1982, despite a 97-win regular season.

namedEntities.name: Dave Roberts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dave Roberts praised Ohtani's performance as the greatest postseason performance of all time, highlighting the significance of the game in team history and reinforcing the emotional impact of Ohtani's performance.

namedEntities.name: Freddie Freeman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dodgers outfielder and former World Series MVP
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Freeman praised Ohtani's performance as 'absolutely incredible' and described it as one of the most memorable moments in baseball history, emphasizing the magnitude of the moment on the biggest stage.

namedEntities.name: Jose Quintana
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Quintana started the game and was the first pitcher to face Ohtani in a postseason game, who hit a leadoff homer off him — a historic moment in baseball history.

namedEntities.name: Roki Sasaki
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sasaki pitched the ninth inning in relief and secured the final out, marking his first successful relief appearance as a closer in the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Pat Murphy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Murphy acknowledged Ohtani's performance as 'iconic' and 'one of the best individual performances ever in postseason baseball,' showing the game's impact even on the opposing team's leadership.

namedEntities.name: Mookie Betts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Betts and Will Smith contributed to the scoring with singles that scored runs after Ohtani's first home run, helping establish the early lead in the game.

namedEntities.name: Will Smith
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Smith recorded a single that scored a run and helped the Dodgers extend their lead following Ohtani’s first home run.

namedEntities.name: Jackson Chourio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Chourio recorded Milwaukee’s first hit of the game, but was stranded by Ohtani’s pitching and defense, highlighting the Dodgers’ dominance.

namedEntities.name: Blake Perkins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Perkins acknowledged that the Brewers' performance was affected by a lack of offensive output and the dominance of the Dodgers’ pitching staff.

namedEntities.name: Caleb Durbin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Durbin scored a run when Brice Turang made a ground ball play, showing the team’s ability to capitalize on defensive opportunities despite early struggles.

namedEntities.name: Brice Turang
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Turang made a key ground ball play that allowed Caleb Durbin to score, contributing to the final scoring in the game.

namedEntities.name: Anthony Banda
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Banda ended the eighth inning, preserving the lead after a baserunner threat and showcasing the team’s strong bullpen performance.

namedEntities.name: Blake Treinen
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Treinen allowed two baserunners in the eighth inning, showing a vulnerability in the bullpen, but the team still managed to secure the win.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Shohei Ohtani delivered a legendary two-way performance in Game 4 of the 2025 National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching a shutout into the seventh inning. The Los Angeles Dodgers used this dominant performance to sweep the Milwaukee Brewers, marking the first time the team has swept an NLCS in 16 years and the first such sweep in a best-of-seven series since 2022. Ohtani’s performance — including the first leadoff homer by a pitcher in MLB history — earned him NLCS MVP honors and is being hailed as one of the greatest individual postseason performances ever. The Dodgers advance to the World Series for the 23rd time in franchise history, aiming to become the first team in 25 years to win back-to-back titles. The Brewers, despite a 97-win regular season, were eliminated for the third time in seven playoff appearances and haven’t reached the World Series since 1982.
title: Shohei Ohtani hits 3 homers and strikes out 10 in Dodgers' clinching 5-1 NLCS win over Brewers
